results.content: So far I think this course is excellent as a walk-through that combines a lot of knowledge about Laravel, though I think there is a small lack in any kind of through-line that would make this is a great course to take for someone new to web development or even to Laravel itself. I am not having any trouble following most of the information presented, but I think that someone who had not already learned about Laravel and tinkered with it to some degree would likely end up a little lost and need to supplement this course with other material to gain a comprehensive understanding of this framework that they could put to practical use.

results.content:
I highly recommend this course to any Laravel Novice who wants to get into this powerful framework and improve their PHP development skills.  The course instructor is very knowledgeable and put complex messages across in a structure way.  

From my personal point of view, this course has achieved objectives beyond my expectations.  As a "Laravel Novice" I was expecting to have several situations that I could not grasp. I was expecting my usual errors due to spelling mistakes, and believe me I made many, but the reality was, I only had one section where I had difficulty grasping the technical aspects. However once  I had taken the time to go back over the section, I understood the concepts ans I achieved the expected results.

Thanks Piotr - A great course! 

P.S. I am hopeful that you might / may be considering an  "Intermediate Laravel" course, which I will purchase of course! Regards Mac

results.content:
Really enjoyed the course!  Very thorough..
I love Piotr's delivery; everything was explained very well.
The only reason I could not give 5.0 stars was because of not answering questions; I had about 8-10 questions throughout the course, and he replied to about 3, and actually answered 1 - a couple other users supplied a couple answers.  I know you have so many students, and these are crazy times with the virus, but I guess I felt just a little abandoned, and this is not a trivial subject, so when I didn't get an answer it bogged me down for several days until I could either find it (which I know is a valuable lesson in and of itself) or my son (another laravel guru) would have the time to help me.
All-in-all it was a very good course and I enjoyed it very much - in fact, I'm going to do your laravel/vue course next!
See you there!

response.content: Thanks John, sorry for not always being there for you! Be sure to join the new Discord community I created to be easier to reach! You can find the link in educational announcements (in both Laravel courses).

results.content:
I bought this course to prepare for an internship as part of my AP degree in Computer Science. Since we're only being taught enterprise Java at school, I needed some way to learn Laravel quick before the internship began, since that's the framework I would be using there.

In preperation I blasted through most of the course in just a few weeks and learned a ton! Everything is thoroughly explained and in great detail. Piotr is very knowledgeable and a good teacher, giving great and practical examples to code along with. 

Equipped with the knowledge I picked up from the course I started my internship, it's now been almost 3 months and last week my boss came and offered me a full time job as a backend Laravel developer, beginning the same day as my internship ends. Taking this course most certainly played a part in helping me achieve that. Thank you!

response.content: Thanks Christian, that's a great story! Can't say how glad I am the course has helped you reach your goals!

Everything is well explained. You get the changes of each single lecture as a git commit in the whole projects repository and thus can view them as a whole afterwards. The course covers every important aspect of laravel and explains it with real world examples that magically all combine to one big whole, a social media app, where you can post posts, post comments to post, categorize and tag posts, sign in as a new user and log in as a user, etc.
As it is one big whole in the end, one can see the whole picture and how each aspect of laravel plays its unreplacable role in it.
Very, very, very well done.

results.content:
This Laravel introducing and intermediate course , is by far one of the best present here on the Udemy platform.

And mark my words on this : I have seen a lot.

----------

There are several things that makes this course pretty good compared to others,

First one, is the teacher's voice intonation and velocity.

The way he speaks, can be slow and monotone for some who already have some knowledge, but on the other hand, it is perfectly fine for those who freshly start learning about this Framework, or are simply interested about enhancing their Laravel's skills. 

These kind of people need to be schooled. Slowly. Step by step. No need to hurry on the voice nor the lesson. So that they make sure to efficiently remember the lessons subjects.

Understand by this, that this course is PRIMARILY NOT for those who have an intermediate+ or advanced level on this framework.

----------

Second one, the content itself.

It isn't a lie to tell you that this course covers almost every subjects about Laravel. 

Actually, the most importants topics about how to build any solid websites, based on the WEB middleware group, are included here.

(This then obviously excludes RESTful API).

----------

Third, the teaching skills.

I really enjoy the fact that this teacher does not only provide you a single way about how to do something, but severals. 

Because this is how it is in Laravel : severals ways are offered to you, to achieve the same goal. All roads lead to Rome some might say.

Also, he gives you little tips that shorten the time taken to do things that usually take plenty of time.

Such as : naming your routes, authorization, middleware, migrations, factories, seeding, artisan commands shortcuts, (...)

There are many others obviously but I cannot list all of them here.

----------

However, I am quiet disappointed about something : I do not see any sections where the teacher explains thoroughly how to deploy our application once it is done.

Is he planning to add it further?

----------

And finally, it will be very suitable for everyone, if he could after this one, release a new course about how to build an API with Laravel and VueJS( for example, since it's built in Laravel).

Just as he did for Symfony 4 and React.

It will be very suitable since nodaways, building RestFul API with a JavaScript front-end, Angular/VueJS/React, is very common.

response.content:
Wow, that's a long feedback! Thanks for taking time to write up! I'll skip what you did like, and will address things you thought are missing: 
- The deployment - yes, this will be definitely added!
- APIs and Vue.js - sure, this will come very soon!
response.content_html:
Wow, that's a long feedback! Thanks for taking time to write up! I'll skip what you did like, and will address things you thought are missing:

results.content: Detailed, in-depth, information not to be easily found elsewhere.  Sure, the downside is this can get a little tedious or pedantic if you're already up to speed on a section but it's priceless if you're not. I'm in no hurry and don't expect to be a Laravel expert by next week; it takes time - lots of it and the pace of this course suits me just fine. If you're not in a hurry, want full understanding, don't want to skip the deeper points and are prepared to be patient in your study, then you'll find no better course anywhere on the Net. Kudos to the author.

results.content:
Hello Piotr,
This tutorial and your program code is very nice, as well as your english is very good, understandable.
The documentation single chapters, very, very good.
I don't know english very well, but I understood your english very well. 
I have not watched their videos until now, what I have seen so far, it is very good and understandable explained.
I would be happy to do a real life project for the next tutorial with Larevel 8, because I would like to know how a professional teacher can go about implementing a project.
e.g. a small Cafe App, 
Customers, categories, products, tables at the cafe where customers are served are also sold externally, nor delivery when customers call. When customers have paid, the table is free for the next customer. To print the receipt at the post office, what has been swapped. If the customers at the table order more, they will add to your order.
I have already written such an app, would you like to have a real app for your student, would everybody expect it?
If you have learned the basic principles of such an app, you can implement it yourself in other projects.

I can recommend this tutorial to anyone who wants to learn Laravel.
With kind regards
from Berlin Celebi

Definitely worth going through, the teacher went above and beyond to make this material very easy to get into.

ORIGINAL: Learning this has been very helpful, but I feel the difficulty curve was higher than expected. The video does not always make things very clear, but luckily I had experience with Entity Framework beforehand, this helps with understanding Eloquent.
If someone were to go into this a complete beginner, I think they'd give up fast, as you would not understand the concepts of migrations and models.
